captions.text:
How do we know we live in three dimensions?
Here's a clue: it's not just that we have

to use three coordinates (like x,y,z, or latitude,
longitude, altitude) to label every point

Mathematicians have showed that it's possible
to fill up 2d or 3d space using a one-dimensional

"space-filling" curve - that means that every
point in 3d space can be labelled using just

one coordinate: our position along the curve!
(it also means that a square and its side

contain the same number of points - crazy,
right?)

So how do we know that we live in three-dimensional
space and not on a one-dimensional line curled

up so much that it looks three-dimensional?
Well, the short answer is that we don't know

– but we DO know that it looks 3d. So how
do we test that?

One way is to look at diffusion of gas - that
is, how a gas spreads out over time. We just

measure the ratio between volume and radius
of the gas cloud:

In one dimension, radius and volume are the
same! (up to a factor)

In 2d, "volume" means area - or radius squared,
and in 3d, "volume" is radius cubed, and so

on for higher dimensions… and 3d is what
we see.

So basically, determining how many dimensions
we live in is just a bunch of hot air!

title: What is a dimension? In 3D...and 2D... and 1D

comments.text:
I'm not entirely sure, but I think, if you use a space filling curve as a 
coordinate axis, your coordinate will always be either 0 or infinity. 
Because this curve needs to be a fractal, what looks like a finite piece of 
it, will actually be infinitely long. Even though a square and a line have 
the same number of points, it doesn't necessarily work. Because when we use 
coordinates, we are not counting the number of points we have passed by. We 
are counting the length (distance) that we have passed by. A line that 
fills up a square must be infinitely long, and even before filling up any 
part of it, it will have to be infinitely long, so our coordinate at any 
point (except in one corner) will be infinity.﻿

comments.text:
How does a square and its side have the same number of points? Please 
explain!﻿
comments.author: Arathi Suraj

comments.text:
No matter what 2 points you pick on a line segment, there's always a point 
in between them (0.1 is between 0 and 1, 0.01 is between 0 and 0.1, etc.), 
so there are an infinite number of points. Likewise, no matter how many 
points you pick on a plane/square, there's always room for another point, 
so there are also an infinite number of points. With a basic understanding 
of math, infinity = infinity, so they both have the same number of points.

What the video doesn't mention is that there are an infinite number of line 
segments that make up a square, so a square has an infinite number of times 
more points that one of its sides, even though they both have infinite 
points. More advanced mathematics proves that some infinities are bigger 
than others.
comments.author: TheAzaka7

comments.text:
The notion of manipulating a "line" so that you need only use one 
coordinate to represent R3 does not contradict the definition of dimension 
from linear algebra. That is, the dimension of a finite vector space is the 
cardinality of a linearly independent spanning set for that space. 
Furthermore, to define such a "manipulated line" parametrically, you would 
require a minimum of 3 vectors in order for it to occupy R3.﻿

comments.author: MultiGoban

comments.text:
+MultiGoban The 1 dimensional curve could be considered 2-dimensional in 
euclidean space, but the whole idea is to represent a different type of 
space. This can be used for modeling a coordinate system or certain 
geometric concepts on a non-euclidean plane , like the surface of the 
earth. E.g. on a sphere, you can have an equilateral triangle with 3 
90-degree angles.

Non-euclidean space can also be used for a mathematical model to represent 
physical properties.There is a model of gravity where you have a 
position-time graph and gravity causes a curve in the time-axis. If an 
object moves linear in relation to the time curve (moves through time at a 
constant rate) its position changes.

You could theoretically model a 10-dimensional universe with a 
1-dimensional coordinate system, but that would be inconvenient and 
unreasonable in most situations. The whole purpose of defining a curved 
dimension is to model things that would be otherwise complicated in 
euclidean geometry.
comments.author: TheAzaka7

I mean using that logic, I can make a 1D line, representing the Multiverse.

comments.author: MultiGoban

comments.text:
Dimensions are mainly linear in euclidean geometry. You can technically 
define a figure that is curved in euclidean space as a single 
axis/dimension in some other form of measuring space. For example, you 
could make one curve y=x^2 and another y=1-2x in euclidean space, then use 
both of those shapes to define a 2-coordinate system in "Kyle Kinkadean 
Space". The mathematicians are simply defining a curve that fills up 
3-dimensional euclidean space and using it as a single axis for their 
1-dimensional space.

comments.author: hello universe

comments.text:
To all the people in the comments that are confused about how we can only 
be in a 1D world curled up to look 3D but it may as well be curled up into 
2D, or how we can traverse this 3D world so many different ways instead of 
being constrained to a 1D path. This video explains dimensions WRONG. A 1D 
world cannot curl up on itself in if there is only 1 direction to move 
along. A string would not bend if it was constrained to one direction of 
motion. Multiple dimensions are constituted of multiple orthogonal 
direction vectors. This means that each measurement of spacial direction 
must be 90 degrees from each other so that neither one involves another. If 
we are all living on a 1D line of space that is curled up then, A) There 
must be 3 dimensional directions available in space for the line to curl up 
though. or B) There must be multiple 1D lines connected all points along 
our 1D line so that we can take free form paths to get from one point to 
another instead of being constrained in every potential motion.﻿

infinite amount of 1-dimensional dimensions to connect each point together 
to give the illusion of a 3-dimensional universe. I'm going to spend 
several weeks looking into this.﻿
comments.author: Jake Hayward

comments.text:
+DJjakedrake In a sense that's what's happening. Think of your stationary 
grid but on planes in every direction imaginable. That's space/time. And 
when the atoms that make up our bodies displace space/time, it envelopes 
us, and that's what gives everything gravity.

The classic example is the Earth/grid example. Imagine the Earth on a 2D 
grid, and it's mass is creating a dip in that grid. That dip is what 
creates gravity. If something gets close enough to the dip, it will fall 
into it. Now, this 2D grid is a simple example of what is happening in 
every direction imaginable.

Since space/time is a 3D idea, one can say that it is stationary relative 
to you as it is expanding as the universe expands. So when you walk a few 
steps, you're displacing that space/time you're walking through, which is 
why you and everything with mass has gravity. And everything with gravity 
has an effect on everything else with mass.

It's wild to think about it, but when you simply jump up, your gravity is 
pulling the Earth towards you to an extremely extremely minute degree as 
the Earth's gravity pulls back on you. It sounds crazy, but science proves 
it. The amount the Earth moves towards you would be 0.0000000000 onto who 
knows how many figures, but it happens.

Same sort of physics and gravity principles that are behind the moon 
creating tides on Earth and minutely affecting its position.

I'm no physicist, just interested immensely in the topic, I'm an aerospace 
engineer (so I know what I need to know about physics, but what I want to 
learn is the PhD type stuff), and what you were saying sounds a lot like 
what happens when matter displaces space/time.
comments.author: Sandra Rios

comments.text:
I've always had this thought: how do we know we're walking through space? 
What if we're on a stationary grid and space is folding around us, in away 
that looks like we're walking through it?
comments.author: DJjakedrake

comments.text:
+Jake Hayward indeed! I used to sympathized with the multiverse 
interpretation of quantum physics, it was very attractive. But most 
recently I've realized that the thought process "it exists simply because 
it can" it is not productive, so I avoid going down that line. But I do 
contemplate the idea of multiverse, remembering the amazing Asimov book 
"The Gods among us", where he explores a creative (imginative) way to "use" 
a cosmeg multiverse to steal energy and ransfer momentum.

But I'm with you, the 1D-verse is a cool idea. Following that logic, any N 
dimensional universe can be traces back to a 1D folded universe in N 
dimensions, which is bizarrely awesome. I deal a lot with big sets of data 
at work (I'm a financial analyses), and I applied this idea to tables. Any 
table with more than 2 dimensions can be summarized in a 2D table by simply 
adding an extra column that represents every coordinate of the extra 
dimensions > 2. :D For example: a 3 dimensional table can be represented by 
a 2D table by simply adding an extra column where each of its rows marks 
the third dimensional measurement (or identity) of that row in the third 
dimension.
comments.author: Lucas Balaminut

comments.text:
+Lucas Balaminut Well, if you look into the multiverse theory, practically 
any possible universe exists and any possible reality (So, not just 
universes which our laws of physics). To make things complicated, a simple 
alternate reality different to ours is one where causes happen after their 
effects - which is very bizzare, whilst very complicated models include a 
universe where there is no such thing as cause and effect yet a reality 
exists. So, to answer you question, a universe like that would exist 
because it could.

I don't think we're in such a universe, I just think the 1-dimensional 
universe is a cool idea to think about. :)
comments.author: Jake Hayward

comments.text: +Sandra Rios thanks for the explanation You guys are very helpful. :D
comments.author: Lucas Balaminut

comments.text:
+Jake Hayward Yes, I do believe it would be instantaneous too, if there are 
only 2 planes connected, that is why I said it would feel like you were 
being teleported. I was referring more to the looks of it.

I think now I understand what you mean by folded. The 1 dimensional world 
would touch itself everywhere, and those touch points would serve as 
wormholes. There would be no difference from a 3D world. Makes sense. No 
need to go through all the trouble of making a flash animation, but thanks 
so much for helping me understand it now :D

If you are right, we can argue that any world with N space dimensions 
(where N is higher than 1) can be equal to 1 dimensional world arranged in 
in a N dimensional space.

Here is my final question: something has to have  perfectly arranged this 1 
dimensional world in a N dimensional space so it feels like it is N 
dimensional world. Any disturbances would look like spacious errors. If so 
is true, what natural forces could cause such arrangement?
comments.author: Lucas Balaminut

comments.text:
+Lucas Balaminut But we were talking hypothetical with the 1 dimension. And 
if that 1 dimension is pretty much infinite (sorry to use a Star 
Trek example, but it applies: They experimented with "infinite speed," 
which made it so that a craft was traveling so fast it was basically 
everywhere at once), and like that example, that 1 line could be so dense 
and pretty much infinite, our brains would spit out a 3D representation of 
our reality. Just like a 4th dimensional being can "see" in 4 dimensions, 
if we're talking a temporal dimension, being able to see all of 3D time at 
once, I think our brains would be able to make sense of the line that is 
everywhere and produce a 3D image. Like a monitor which is flat but 
produces 3D appearing images with a foreground and a background, especially 
if it's a 3D setup.

And a company called Holho, I believe it is, created a 3D hologram device 
that uses projections from the 2D plane of a tablet or smartphone. If such 
things can be done with well placed mirrors and glass, I think our brains 
could spit out a 3D image of a 1D universe that is almost infinitely dense 
with that one line.

Who knows? We were just speaking hypothetical, we live in 3D specially as 
proven by the behavior of gas, but we were just throwing around what ifs, 
so no need to get too serious about this. :)

Peace.
comments.author: Sandra Rios

comments.text:
Sorry about the length :L It's just, I've been looking a lot into 
dimensions lately, and it's really hard to explain through even verbal 
communication in person. I have to make sure my knowledge is as specific 
and accurate as possible so my projects are realistic and have as few 
errors as possible.
comments.author: Jake Hayward

comments.text:
+Lucas Balaminut I've watched interstellar (Pretty much a better Gravity in 
my humble opinion), but it is still fictional. To determine what a wormhole 
looks like, we need to witness one in reality (Although, I do believe that 
it will look somewhat like it did in Interstellar). I don't think it's what 
would happen if we travelled through one, however. I'd imagine it'll be 
instantaneous depending on how close the dimensions were folded 
(Instantaneous if the two folds were in contact). I don't think I can 
explain it in the comments, but I'm sure if a 1-dimensional reality was 
folded through 3 dimensions so that it pretty much covers every point you'd 
expect to achieve in a third dimension, every atom, photon, fundamental 
particle and field would instantaneously travel through to another point in 
the 1-dimension and seem like it's moving through 3-dimensions because the 
folds are in contact with every possible point.

I could try to do an animation to help visualize it because it's hard to 
explain unless you're experienced in the physics of lower and higher 
dimensions, but in the meantime this comment is going to be as much 
information as I can convey.

E.g. an ant on a piece of paper, a 2-dimensional world. If I fold the two 
ends through the third dimension, the ant can move across the 3rd dimension 
to reach the other end, but to the ant, it will still look like a 2d world. 
Now, If I get a sheet of paper and fold it five times so that it is 32 
sheets thick, the ant can move alongside the 2-dimensional tops, but will 
be able to go up and down, still likely without knowing it's traveling 
through 3-dimensions, but that's only if only senses through movement. If 
it could detect photons, which would also pass through the points where the 
2-dimensions are folding, the photon would carry the information of another 
sheet, so the ant would see another sheet, despite not being there. If an 
entity evolved in the folded dimension, it would be able to comprehend the 
3-dimensional folds, and be able to experience a 3-dimensional reality 
because it’s utilising the particles that are falling into the folds.

Now, image the 3-dimensional world is actually constructed of instead of 32 
folds, an infinite amount of folds so that it covers every point in the 3rd 
dimension, so photons would travel through the folds, atoms, electrons 
etc... That would appear to be a straight line when looking at it in 
3-dimensions, but in the 1-dimensional realm, looks like it’s appearing 
then vanishing in an instant, which it would be in reality. We would evolve 
to detect those and because they're travelling across the folded 
1-dimensional space through the 3rd, we can't help but comprehend a 
3-dimensional universe because of the nature of the universe and how we 
evolved in it; like time dilation. We can't comprehend when there's time 
dilation affecting us, because we slow down with it. We would be able to 
comprehend time dilation if we were extremely large beings with some form 
of organ that 'ticks' however, because we'll be able to compare how fast 
it's 'ticking' compared to another part of your body. So in summary, yes, a 
1-dimensional being would see it as completely distorted space that makes 
no sense, but we don’t comprehend the 1-dimensional universe because we 
evolved through the result of the folding through 3-dimensions and utilise 
the mechanics of how folded dimensions work.


After saying all that though, it would still mean the universe has to have 
2 extra dimensions so that the 1st dimension is able to fold through. I

touching, and then despite the page still being 2-dimensional, allows 
people to travel through the connected point. What I think minutephysics is 
saying here, is that a 1 dimension folded through 3 dimensions will produce 
a 1-dimensional universe that looks 3-dimensional, just like a 
3-dimensional universe folded through the 4-th dimension allows for 
wormholes :)

comments.text:
What if there are dimensions we can't directly measure? Imagine you're on a 
space craft that has rockets to move up and down and rockets to move left 
and right, but no rockets to move forward and backward. You may be moving 
forward at some speed, but you can't change our speed in that direction. 
You can only measure the effects of moving in that direction (like noticing 
that things moving slower than you, pass you by or that stars in front of 
you seem more blue than stars behind you). Now imagine that nothing, not 
even particles have a way to effect their forward/backward velocity. A gas 
on your ship would spread out in a 2D disk.

This seems to me to be the case, because light doesn't move through time 
and is the primary force carrying particle. Therefore, other particles 
can't change each other's velocity through time if all their interactions 
are mediated by photons.

Am I missing something? Is this an accurate interpretation?﻿
comments.author: Abe Dillon

comments.text:
Ok, if there are a few points about that: if additional dimensions exist, 
particles have to be able to travel through them like through any of the 
other dimensions, unless there is something physical preventing the 
particles from doing so (like that the additional dimensions are only 
microscopic or something similar). And so far no particle was ever observed 
to travel through additional dimensions, despite extensive searches (and 
ongoing searches). So one could say that so far it looks like either 
additional dimensions do not exist, or nothing we know of ever travels 
through them.

Light does move though time. Unfortunately, you are mixing up the Newtonian 
notion of time with the Einsteinian. In Einstein's picture light always 
moves with a constant velocity through spacetime and that is true for the 
perspective of all observers (that is actually one of the most important 
points about it). However: the proper time of a light-ray is 0. Always. But 
that also means you cannot use the proper time in a system that is 
traveling with the speed of light as a parameter to describe it's path or 
interactions. But this does not mean nothing is happening from the 
perspective of a lightray. In reality, since the proper time between two 
events is 0 for a photon, it would look like everything is happening 
instantly ;)

comments.author: 101jir

comments.text:
What about the homotopy group's? In fact we know that 1D (R1), 2D (R2) and 
3D (R3) are not topologically the same thing. For example the real line R 
is not homeomorphic to the plane R2, the prove goes as follows: suppose 
there were a homeomorphism h of R onto R2. Select some point x0 e R. The 
restriction of h to R-(x0) would then carry it homeomorphically onto 
R2-(h[x0]). However, R-(x0) is not connected, whereas R2-(h[x0]) certainly 
is connected . Since connectedness is a topological property, this cannot 
be and we have our contradiction. We can use a similar argumet between R2 
and R3, R3 is simply connected and R2 is not. 
   Think now in a point electric charge "q" residing at the origin of some 
intertial frame of reference. The electric field E satisfy the static, 
source-free maxwell equations divE=0, curlE=0 (idem with B) in R3-(0,0,0) . 
Because of the “simply connectedness” property of R3 we can guarantee the 
existence of a scalar potencial function whose gradient is E and solve the 
problem, therefore electromagnetism and this kind of phenomena tells us 
information about the topology and dimension that could have the space.﻿
comments.author: Benjamín Marcolongo

comments.text:
the vector potencial gives no observable phenomena in classical

effect for actually measure the topology in the space. You can use this 
kind of experiment to argue that our universe is a four dimensional 
manifold.

comments.author: Sarah Kettell

comments.text:
Space filling curves aren't at all what you are saying. If you truly fill 
space (be it 2-D or 3-D) using only a 1D line, then for any points A and B 
in the curve, if you were to follow the line from A to B, you'd travel an 
infinite distance. So, it's not like we could use only one coordinate that 
would tell you the position in the line (and therefore in the space) you 
are at, all the points are infinitely distant from one another so there is 
no metric. You NEED more dimensions to fully describe the space.

What you CAN argue is that you can do an approximation of a space filling 
curve. A 1-D line that does not pass through every point in space, but that 
passes nearby every point in space. And by nearby i mean that the shortest 
distance from any point in space to that line is always smaller than the 
Planck's length. Then, you *could* argue that you can describe 3-D space 
using only one coordinate, because any distance smaller than the Plank's 
length doesn't make much sense, and therefore, as far as your calculations 
are concerned, the line does pass through every point in space, and is 
1-D. ﻿

You could say "I'm at atom 35", or " I've just passed atom 3656711" and so 
on... You migt think this method is really imprecise - atoms have width 
after-all, so even if you are on an atom, you still don't have a precise 
coordinate. So to solve that repeat the above steps, but instead of using 
atoms, use plank lengths, and there you go, a 1 coordinate system which can 
precisely define any point in a 3d space

comments.text:
For Emmanuel, try reading flatland or a book that describes the concepts 
discussed in flatland. A principal wrote it i think, and it is definitely 
aimed at simplifying the discussion. The basic crux of the book is that in 
a 2 dimensional world the creatures that exist would not be able to 
recognise a 3 dimensional object. 
Simplest example, if a sphere passed through flat land it would start as a 
dot, keep getting bigger, reach its maximum diameter then start shrinking 
until just a dot remains, then nothing. Observing this outside of Flatland 
we see a dot become a circle, reach its maximum then shrink away to 
nothing. The Flatlanders on the other hand can only only exist on 2 
dimensional plane, so for them all they would see is a dot appear, expand 
to its maximum, then shrink away and be gone. 
The point is, would we even recognise another dimension?﻿

comments.text:
+StarLink149 I like the Pac-Man explaination. I disagree with you on the 
point that the universe has to be infinite though.
You see, infinity in space can be disproven but not proven, whereas finity 
in space can be proven but not disproven. Since infinity in space cannot be 
proven in any way, it's not logical to assume that the universe is in fact 
infinite. What's more, science favours simple theories over complex ones 
with the same amount of proof, and infinity is an infinitly complex thing, 
whereas finity is relatively easy to understand depending on how big it is, 
so science would favour a finite universe theory over an infinite one.

anything, it's just expanding), meaning that distances between remote 
objects become larger, and eventually, this will happen to objects closer 
to each other, as the force that stretches the space between them becomes 
larger than gravity. So basically, the room itself is expanding, But since 
the walls of the room are impossible to find (because the point where the 
universe starts repeating itself is a matter of perspective), we also can't 
point out a center of expantion. And here it becomes interesting, because 
that means that from the perspective of any given place in the universe, 
everything is driven away from that point, so from anyones perspective they 
are Always the center of the expansion, or, if you will, the center of the 
universe.

comments.author: Roberto Fontiglia

comments.text:
+Roberto Fontiglia I think it's be more accurate to say it is analogous to 
a fractal path, then, but I got what you mean and it is quite similar. The 
lack of definitive distance, however, lies not on the consecutive 
distances, but on the spatial distance.

Imagine, if you will, a line that goes 1 step forward and one back, moving 
a single point sideways on return. Now, if it does that an infinite amount 
of times, that line will now cover an area. The 2D distance between the 
first point and the point right besides it (not along the line, but across) 
is much smaller than the sum of consecutive distances. In that way, it is, 
in our common conventions, undefined.
comments.author: Zack Dark

comments.text:
+Zack Dark Well, +Dan Eisenhauer said that you couldn't point to any point 
on an infinite space-filling one-dimensional curve and tell how far along 
the line it was from an arbitrary origin. The implication being that this 
quantity is not well defined. How can that be so ? One of the very 
important property of fractals is specifically this : that the distance 
between two points along a fractal path is undefined.

You can define the distance between two points A and B along a curve as the 
limit of the sum of the consecutive distances of n points on the curve 
between A and B. As n goes to infinity, obviously, the n intermediate 
points will come closer and closer together, and the sum of the distances 
between consecutive points should converge towards the curvilinear distance 
between A and B.

However, if the curve is a fractal, this is not the case; the sum of the 
distances between the n consecutive points just blows up as n tends to 
infinity. Result : the distance between A and B along a fractal path is 
undefined.
comments.author: Roberto Fontiglia

comments.text: +Roberto Fontiglia What would make you come to that conclusion? O_o

comments.text:
Fourth dimension doesn't always represent time, it depends on who you are 
talking to.
- If you talk to a physicist that is working with the Theory of Special 
Relativity for example, to him the fourth in his calculations represents 
time.

- If you speak to a mathematician, dimension is just a mathematical tool. 
You could calculate geometrical system that have 100 dimensions if you 
wish, it just simply adding another member to a vector (x,y,z,t,s.......z)

-And then there are theoretical physicists that use the mathematical tool 
of dimension to represent space beyond our own. To them space can be 
complex and would need to be represented by a large vector. However not 
like the mathematician they try to base it in reality. The entire vector 
however is used to represent space unlike the first group.

comments.text: well, theres entropy
comments.author: Samuel Jackson

comments.text:
Well, time is nothing absolutely. It's not like time's ticking the same for 
everything in the universe. When you put a heavy ball on a mattress, the 
mattress will bend around it. The higher its weight, the more it bends. 
With time it's pretty much the same. So time does exist, it just depends on 
the object experiencing it, on the one hand on the physical factor, on the 
other hand on the psychic factor. Because we experience time different from 
situation to situation. It's a pretty interesting issue you're bringing up 
there because time of course is nothing insisting out of matter (at least 
as far as we do know) so we can't measure it or observe it in any way. 
Everything we do know about it could be wrong, but this way we at least can 
make up pretty much every theory about it. I'm not really sure what you do 
mean with the cat thing, maybe you could explain it to me.
comments.author: Klaus “The Cloud” Kleber

comments.text: to me time is just a named process. process of all things in the world.
comments.author: vim viva

comments.text:
You are kind of correct. Time is different to each person and a second to 
me isn't the same as a second to you it's all weird. Because you would 
think that time stays the same, but in actual fact light stays the same.

All according to our best theories.
comments.author: patdaman12

comments.text:
what if back in time(if time exists O.o), humans started thinking in more 
than 3 dimensions? is it excally the world that is in 3 dimensions, or our

comments.author: Stijn Dijkstra

comments.text:
Some scientists think there is an infinite amount of dimensions. Only we 
cannot perceive each of them. We can only perceive the third dimension and 
lower. Shapes in the dimension zero is basically constitued of points so 
small they can hardly be seen individually. Dimension one consists of 
lines, as shown by this video. Dimension two consists of planes and 
dimension three of 3D solids. Now, this is where it gets complicated. 
Dimensions four and higher are constitued of solids whose name start with 
the prefix "hyper", such as Hypercube, Hyperpyramid, etc. It has nothing to 
see with time. Just as 3D shapes look like 2D shapes placed in front of 
another, think of them as 3D shapes placed in front of another. Also, I 
encourage you to look for "hypercube rotation" on Google. :)
comments.author: StarLink149

comments.text:

physics say). So unless space doesn't exist then time doesn't.

Space time is one thing, but the volume of a 4th dimensional object can't 
be represented by r^4. The only way that makes sense is if you're storing 
things in time.

comments.text:
The fourth spatial dimension is spatial. :p
Spacetime is what we supposedly live in, where there are three spatial 
dimensions, plus time as the fourth.
comments.author: Gheiter

comments.text:
This reminds me of an arguement I had with a friend a long time ago. 3D 
movies (the crappy kind with the red and blue glasses) were all the rage 
where I live at the time. My friend asked why you call a game on 
PlayStation 3D when it isn't actually. I tried to explain that the games 
image is rendered in 3D, but since the television set can't output a 3D 
image, the picture itself is 2D. We would talk about this for hours on end, 
never settling the argument... Ah, good times.﻿
comments.author: toshineon

comments.text:
I see, that makes sense. So, that relies on preexisting knowledge of the 
length of that string and exactly how it curves, etc. if you want to find a 
specific point on the sphere. Doesn't make things easy, but I guess you can 
use one dimensional coordinates to locate things in 3D space. Kinda cool!
comments.author: Jakob Orkin

comments.text:
it doesnt matter how thin the noodle is. The noodle would be still 3d since 
it can fill out a form (?)
comments.author: CrystalChandrians

comments.text:
You can't, because if something is curved then it automatically has more 
than 1 dimension. If you have a piece of string, hypothetically it is 1 
dimensional. But as soon as you pull on the middle of the string, you are 
pulling in a new direction - thus making it 2D.
comments.author: Shorjok

comments.text:
Imagine making a gigantic massive sphere out of one single super long 
measured string. Each different point of this string is a different 3D 
point in your sphere. So you can use a single dimensional point to describe 
a three-dimensional point
comments.author: Juan Fuentes

comments.text:
But... That just implies that everything is connected. That isn't one 
dimensional...
comments.author: Jakob Orkin

comments.text: Just imagine a super long spaghetti that fills the entire universe.
comments.author: Jake Long

comments.text:
imagine a 2d grid labled 0 through 4 on one axis, and A through E on the 
other. the result is a list of intersections in the format of 0A, 4B, 2E, 
and so on. now imagine you have a 1d line (with no curves), that has the 
following points marked on it, in this order: A0, A1, A2, A3, A4, B4, B3, 
B2, B1, B0, C0, C1, C2, C3, C4, etc. if you were to go back to the 2d grid 
and draw a line from each point in that series to the next, you will find 
that the resulting line curves over the 2d space.
comments.author: Raymi Hennessey

comments.text: My curve fills the universe.
comments.author: Xiclotrode

comments.text:
He used what's called a Peano Curve. However I'm not sure that using a 
Peano curve would allow us to live in one dimension: as a matter of fact, 
to describe a peano curve we need as many variables as are needed to 
describe the space in which it "lives" (its domain), so we would end up 
with a way to univocally find a point on a curve that is in itself defined 
by three parameters, which means we live in a 3d space. I'm not sure 
though, so correct me if I'm wrong.
comments.author: stefano franzini

comments.text: You use a space filling curve. Didn't you hear that?
